It has but this one fault. Under its provision, a man or a people who are able to protect themselves can get along well enough; but those who have the misfortune to be weak or unpopular are left to the merciless rage of popular fury.

The Constitution should contain a provision that every officer of the Government who should neglect2 or refuse to extend the protection guaranteed in the Constitution should be subject to capital punishment; and then the president of the United States would not say, “Your cause is just, but I can do nothing for you,” a governor issue exterminating orders, or judges say, “The men ought to have the protection of law, but is won’t please the mob; the men must die, anyhow, to satisfy the clamor of the rabble; they must be hung, or Missouri be damned to all eternity.” Executive writs could be issued when they ought to be, and not be made instruments of cruelty to oppress the innocent,3 and persecute men whose religion is unpopular.

The Creeds of Men

I cannot believe in any of the creeds of the different denominations,4 because they all have some things in them I cannot subscribe to, though all of them have some truth. I want to come up into the presence of God,5 and learn all things; but the creeds set up stakes, and say, “Hitherto shalt thou come, and no further”;6 which I cannot subscribe to.

Errors in the Bible

I believe the Bible as it read when it came from the pen of the original writers.7 Ignorant translators, careless transcribers, or designing and corrupt priests8 have committed many errors. As it read, Gen. 6:6, “It repented the Lord that he had made man on the earth”;9 also, Num. 23:19, “God is not a man, that he should lie; neither the Son of man, that he should repent”;10 which I do not believe. But it ought to read, “It repented Noah that God made man.”11 This I believe, and then the other quotation stands fair. If any man will prove to me, by one passage of Holy Writ, one item I believe to be false, I will renounce12 and disclaim it as far as I promulgated13 it.
